description: From Middle English enamouren, a late back-formation from enamoured, itself a partial calque of Old French enamore, past participle of enamorer, enamourer, equivalent to prefix en- +‎ amor +‎ -er. See amour, and compare inamorato.

verbs.description: enamor (third-person singular simple present enamors, present participle enamoring, simple past and past participle enamored) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: (mostly in the passive, followed by "of" or "with") To cause to be in love.
examples: He was offered a chair in the university and a course abroad. But he hesitated. There was a girl of whom he became enamored, so he contemplated marriage and political activity.
Passionately enamoured of this shadow of a dream.
